title: 115_s1321
content: The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" aims to hold advisors accountable for providing impermissible advice or breaching the best interest standard for investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" aims to define investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, specifying recommendations related to acquiring, holding, disposing, or exchanging plan assets, as well as managing plan funds. The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" defines investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, including recommendations on managing plan funds and retaining advisors. The advice must be provided in writing or through a mutual agreement with limitations on scope, timing, and ongoing responsibility. The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" outlines the definition of investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, emphasizing the need for recommendations to be individualized and relied upon by the plan. Any disclaimer must be in writing and clearly communicated to the recipient. The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" defines investment advice under ERISA, requiring recommendations to be personalized and relied upon by the plan. Information without a disclaimer and provided in a marketing or sales capacity is not considered a recommendation under certain conditions. The person providing information must not give investment advice or act under the best interest standard. They can provide information if they are a counterparty or service provider to the plan, as long as the plan is represented by an independent plan fiduciary. The independent plan fiduciary must confirm in writing that they are aware of the person's financial interest in the transaction and that the person is not providing investment advice or acting as a fiduciary to the plan. The person providing information to the plan must disclose in writing that they are not providing investment advice as a fiduciary. The information consists of making securities available to the plan without considering individualized needs, for plan fiduciaries to select or monitor investment alternatives. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for identifying investment alternatives for individual accounts in connection with a platform or similar mechanism. It also mentions providing objective financial data and comparisons with independent benchmarks to the plan. The information may consist solely of valuation information or information described in Department of Labor Interpretive Bulletin 96-1. The curr_chunk discusses providing information to participants or beneficiaries on factors to consider when deciding on a distribution from a plan or individual retirement plan. This information should include examples of distribution and rollover alternatives. The curr_chunk discusses exemptions related to investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, including conditions for transactions and reasonable compensation. The curr_chunk discusses the disclosure requirements for investment advice, including limitations on compensation and the need to inform recipients about alternative investment options. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of disclosing variable compensation in investment advice, including informing recipients about the availability of similar investments at different costs from other sources. The curr_chunk highlights the necessity of notifying individuals about potential fees and compensation related to investment recommendations. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of disclosing various types of compensation related to investment transactions, including indirect compensation from third parties. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions for recommendations to satisfy disclosure requirements related to compensation in investment transactions. It includes provisions for correcting errors or omissions in disclosing information to the advice recipient. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is the date of enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this Act regarding disclosure requirements for compensation in investment transactions will take effect on the enactment date. Grandfathered transactions and services are exempt, and until regulations are issued, compliance with a good faith interpretation is sufficient.
